title: R41010
content: The Supreme Court has held in abeyance the question of whether a demonstration of actual innocence would warrant federal habeas relief. Davis's habeas petition was transferred to the U.S. District Court, which concluded that the constitutional right exists but denied habeas relief. The Supreme Court declined to review the lower court opinion, leaving the underlying question unresolved. Davis was convicted of murder and other charges. Davis was convicted of murder, obstruction of a police officer, aggravated assault, and possession of a firearm during a felony. The victim was a police officer shot while responding to a disturbance. Davis was sentenced to death for the murder. He petitioned for habeas relief based on newly discovered evidence and alleged prosecutorial misconduct. Davis petitioned for a new trial based on recantations of witnesses, statements from new witnesses, and evidence pointing to another suspect. The Georgia Supreme Court denied his petition, with dissenting members believing his new evidence was not given enough weight. Davis then sought approval from the federal court of appeals for a second habeas petition. The federal court of appeals denied Davis's application for a second federal habeas petition, stating that he failed to meet the requirements for presenting new evidence or proving a constitutional error that would establish his innocence of the murder he was convicted of. The federal court of appeals denied Davis's application for a second federal habeas petition, stating that he failed to meet the requirements for presenting new evidence or proving a constitutional error that would establish his innocence of the murder he was convicted of. The dissenting member of the panel argued that the application to permit a second habeas petition should be granted when a death row inmate makes a viable claim of actual innocence. Davis filed a petition with the Supreme Court, which transferred it to the United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia for further review. The district court was instructed to determine if evidence not available at the time of trial clearly establishes Davis's innocence, and to consider that certain provisions of the Anti-terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act may not apply to habeas corpus petitions filed under the Supreme Court's original jurisdiction. The Supreme Court transferred Davis's habeas corpus petition to the district court for further review. Justice Stevens suggested avenues to relief in response to Justice Scalia's dissent, stating that AEDPA may not preclude a claim of actual innocence in this case. The court may find it relevant to the AEDPA analysis that Davis is bringing an 'actual innocence' claim, potentially leading to relief for a death row inmate who has established his innocence. The district court believes that section 2244(b)'s jurisdictional bar on second or successive habeas petitions does not apply to petitions filed originally with the Supreme Court. The Judiciary Act of 1789 granted the Supreme Court and district courts the power to issue writs of habeas corpus for inquiries into the cause of commitment. Congress later expanded federal courts' jurisdiction to issue the writ in all cases, state or federal. Congress expanded federal courts' jurisdiction to issue writs of habeas corpus in all cases, state or federal, where a person may be restrained of their liberty in violation of the constitution, treaty, or US law. The Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction over habeas decisions of lower federal courts was clarified, except for military prisoners. The first case under this new authority involved William McCardle, a Mississippi newspaper editor arrested by military authorities for inciting insurrection. His habeas corpus petition was denied by the federal circuit court, leading to an appeal to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court denied the government's motion to dismiss the appeal in the case of Ex parte McCardle, as the military custody exception did not apply to the pre-existing habeas authority of the Judiciary Act of 1789. However, Congress later repealed the law vesting appellate jurisdiction in the Court, leading to the dismissal of the appeal for want of jurisdiction. This decision clarified that the Court's loss of jurisdiction in habeas cases did not affect its ability to review lower court decisions. The Supreme Court's jurisdiction to hear appeals in habeas cases did not mean the loss of its ability to review lower court decisions. The review process remained available, although it required using both the writ of certiorari and the writ of habeas corpus. The Court confirmed its jurisdiction under writs of habeas corpus and certiorari to review cases, even after the 1868 Act repealed appellate jurisdiction vested in the Court. The 1868 Act repealed appellate jurisdiction held by the Court, but did not affect its authority to review habeas cases through writs of habeas corpus and certiorari. Congress later restored the Court's jurisdiction to review habeas cases in 1885. The original writ of habeas corpus in the Supreme Court was rarely successful and was urged for effective abandonment. In Boumediene v. Bush, the issue of Congress's authority to restrict habeas corpus access was addressed. The Court concluded that the suspension clause has full effect at Guantanamo Bay and that the Military Commission Act did not formally suspend the writ. It also examined whether the statute stripping jurisdiction for habeas corpus provided adequate substitute procedures, finding little precedent to guide this assessment. The Supreme Court in Boumediene v. Bush addressed the issue of restricting habeas corpus access for foreign nationals detained in Guantanamo. The Court identified essential features of habeas corpus and any adequate substitute, emphasizing the prisoner's right to demonstrate errors in the application of law and the importance of rigorous review in detention cases. The Supreme Court found the Detainee Treatment Act procedures inadequate as a substitute for normal habeas procedures, ruling that the Military Commissions Act's attempt to limit habeas jurisdiction for Guantanamo detainees is unconstitutional. The court emphasized the need for the habeas proceeding to have the authority to correct errors, assess evidence, and consider relevant exculpatory evidence. The Supreme Court has ruled that the prospect of innocence can serve as a gateway for habeas review of a state prisoner's constitutionally defective conviction or sentence. This exception allows for consideration of new evidence that could prove actual innocence, requiring the petitioner to show a constitutional violation likely led to the conviction of an innocent person. The Supreme Court has set standards for habeas petitions based on actual innocence. The petitioner must show clear evidence that without constitutional error, no reasonable juror would have imposed the death penalty. This standard is less demanding than the one required for insufficient evidence of guilt to issue the writ. In Herrera v. Collins, the Court addressed a claim of actual innocence without constitutional defect in a capital case, highlighting the disruptive effect on finality in capital cases. The petitioner sought habeas relief based on newly discovered evidence of innocence, challenging the need for finality in such cases. The Court emphasized the need for finality in capital cases and the high threshold for assuming a right to retry cases based on stale evidence. The petitioner in this case did not meet this threshold, and the Court stated that the Constitution may preclude the execution of an undisputedly innocent individual. Davis faces a challenge in presenting evidence to meet this standard, as shown in the District Court's analysis. The question remains whether the Eighth Amendment prohibits executing an actually innocent defendant. The Eighth Amendment's cruel and unusual punishment clause condemns punishments that offend evolving standards of decency. Most states have statutes allowing innocent defendants to challenge their capital convictions, and the Supreme Court only permits execution after establishing responsibility for the death of another. The District Court reasoned that the Eighth Amendment prohibits the execution of the actually innocent and set a high standard for proving innocence. Despite some doubt cast on his conviction by new evidence, the majority of trial evidence remained intact and the new evidence was deemed not credible or lacking in probative value. The District Court found that Mr. Davis failed to prove his actual innocence, leading the Supreme Court to dismiss the case without a written opinion on March 28, 2011.
